resource.chars:
No. 20. A thread of Sheeps <s>Woll <\s> Wool, which is broken, and ap 
pears to consist of many lesser threads.
The Instrument whence a Spider spins <s>his <\s> the threads that com 
pose his Web.
No. 21. A Granade, or spark made in striking <s>Tire <\s> Fire.
The Vessels in a leaf of Tea.
No. 22. The <u>Animalcula in Semine Masculino <\u>, of a Lamb taken 
from the Testicle jul.24.1702.
A piece of the Tongue of a hog. full of sharp points.
No. 23. A fibre of Codfish, consisting of long slender particles.
Another of the same.
No. 24. A filament, conveying nourishment to the Nutmeg, cut 
transeversely.
Another piece of the same in which the figure of the vessels 
may be seen.
No. 25. part of the bone or tooth abovementioned, consisting of 
hollow Pipes.
An Exceeding thin Membrane, being that which coverd a
very small muscle.
No. 26. Vessels by which Membranes receive nourishment and encrease.
A bunch of hair from the insect calld hair worm.
No. 27. The Double silk, spun by the worm.
The organ of sight of a flie.

It were endless to enter into any particulars, of what is to be observd 
in any of these objects, or indeed to give any account of Mr Lewenhoecks 
discoverys; they are so numerous as to make up a considerable part 
of the Philosophical Transactions, and when collected together, to fill 
4 pretty large volumes in Quarto, which have been publisht by him
at several times: and of such consequence as to have opend entirely 
new scenes in some parts of Natural Philosophy, as we are all sensible
